posts.name: Alexander Hamilton
posts.cooked:
Hi, We are currently undergoing some problems with CAN Utilization on our robot. We are currently running 17 Neos (mix of 550, v1.1, and vortex) and a Pigeon 2.0 from CTRE . We pay very close attention to what kinds of information in which we ask the motors to send, and limit all of the data we don‚Äôt want to the max allowed delay between each send (65535ms). Our setCANTimeout() is currently set to 50ms, but we noticed some teams setting it to zero to make them check on another thread. Lastly, we use URCL to log all of the data from the sparks when we get them, but that is told to only log at the rate at which it is received, which explains why disabling it makes no difference to the overall utilization. We generally sit around 98% CAN Utilization , which is very concerning considering that other people around here say that 80% or more start to cause problems.

When setting every single periodic status frame to 65535ms , when looking at URCL in AdvantageScope, the motor data seems to be updating extremely fast (over five times per second at least). This means that the overall CAN Utilization is still at record-high values, even though we aren‚Äôt commanding the motors to do anything. This is leading me to believe that the parameters on the sparks aren‚Äôt being set, which really confused me when I found that all of the REVLibErrors in setPeriodicStatusFrame() were returning kOk.

I have noticed that the only parameter that makes any difference on overall utilization is setCANTimeout() which makes the overall utilization around 80% with the tradeoff that we have a low timeout, but the periodic status frames are still not appearing to set.

If needed, will provide some code snippets, although I don‚Äôt think they are strictly needed for this situation. Either way, if anyone has any questions or solutions please let me know.

posts.name: Lexeo
posts.cooked:
GalexY:

or solutions

I actually may have one for you.

We had a similar issue 2 days ago. We were setting things to 65535ms to ‚Äúturn them off‚Äù and were seeing basically no change.

What we did to fix this, is started setting things to 500 ms instead, just to make the frame rate extremely slow, effectively doing the same thing. This was the number recommended in the Rev documentation. We were surprised that solved our issue.

I wondering if setting the rate to 65535ms is doing something weird. 500ms seems to be working better.

Where we were:

image 1536√ó892 67.7 KB

image 1536√ó892 67.7 KB

Where we are now:

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked: How are you generating the data for that graph?

posts.name: Jainish Patel
posts.cooked: AdvantageScope to visualize it. You have to put your data fields on NetworkTables or log it.

posts.name: Alexander Hamilton
posts.cooked:
Lexeo:

What we did to fix this, is started setting things to 500 ms instead, just to make the frame rate extremely slow, effectively doing the same thing. This was the number recommended in the Rev documentation. We were surprised that solved our issue.

Phenomenal. We finally were able to drop to roughly 60% utilization. Thank you so much for your insight. I got a little comfortable and used 10000ms rather than 500ms, and it still appears to work fine.

posts.name: Alexander Hamilton
posts.cooked:
UPDATE! I emailed REV about this matter and this was their response: Apparently its a signed int rather than unsigned, which reduced the number from 65535 to 32767 IMG_7500 1076√ó279 76.1 KB

IMG_7500 1076√ó279 76.1 KB

IMG_7500 1076√ó279 76.1 KB

link_counts.title: RevLib's Documented Maximum Status Frame Period Limit Is Wrong

posts.name: amber
posts.cooked: Interesting, why would a status frame period be a signed value?

posts.name: Jeffrey Morris
posts.cooked: obviously so you can get status frames from the future smh.
